properties.name: BimBam
properties.description:
This is a game example to show how to use a graph extension to create match-3 games with GDevelop. The source can be found directly in GDevelop in the examples list.

Controls are arrows and left-shift or mouse.

events.comment:
The bubbles are linked to their neighbors to allow to find aggregation in the "Board Resolution" section.

2 instances of the same object can't be linked together so 2 objects are used:
- BoardBubble, linked to a superposing and hidden LinkBubble
- LinkBubble, linked to its neighbors BoardBubble

LevelBubble is a group that contains one object for each color because it's easier to design level that way, but it's not used for the gameplay.
The level may not use every 5 bubble colors.

Let time for the launcher to point toward the mouse.
The 3 margin is because the mouse is followed by simulating key press.
So, it won't stop right toward the mouse beause of inertia.

Aim exactly at the mouse.
It also allows to aim without hovering, on a touch device for instance.
The mustGlue variable avoid to have the BoardBuble from the collision in the context because otherwise it will change color too.
Avoid to snap bubbles on the column on the scene edge
A Mark is linked to the new BoardBubble to know where to look for the board resolution.
Link the new bubble to the other bubbles of the board

The start location of the aggregation search is marked by the Mark.
It finds a LinkedBubble aggregation of a given color.

6, because LikedBubble are BoardBubble + LinkBubble.
See the "Level Link Graph" section to understand why this is needed.
Create the FaillingBubbles for the falling animation

Now that the targeted bubbles may be removed from the board, there could be bubbles in the air.
A bubble is in the air if there is no path (from link to link) from the TopBorder to this bubble.
Create the FaillingBubbles for the falling animation
Animation of the bubble falling from the board
The BoardBubble is linked with its shadow LinkBubble...

...and the shadow LinkBubble is linked to its neighbors.
So, the BoardBubbles are linked to their neighbors through LinkBubbles.
This is needed because the link action can't be used on 2 BoardBubble direcly.

This links are used to look for aggregations of bubbles of a same color.
(See the "Board resolution" section)

Link the 1st bubble row to the top border. This will allow to look for unheld bubbles.
(See the "Board resolution - Unheld bubles" section)
Find which colors are still on the board because only these colors will be given to the player when he shoots.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: D8H
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: HexagonalGrid
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Snap objects to an hexagonal grid.
description: It allows to snap objects on an hexagonal grid.
It's useful for:
- level editors
- building systems ([open the city builder example online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://city-builder))
A [simple example](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://snap-object-to-grid) shows how to snap objects that are dragged with the mouse.

eventsFunctions.description: Snap object to a virtual pointy topped hexagonal grid (this is not the grid used in the editor).
eventsFunctions.fullName: Snap objects to a virtual pointy topped hexagonal grid
eventsFunctions.name: SnapObjectToPointyToppedHexagonalGrid
eventsFunctions.sentence: Snap _PARAM1_ to a virtual pointy topped hexagonal grid using cells with width: _PARAM2_px, height _PARAM3_px and an offset position (_PARAM4_; _PARAM5_)

inlineCode: // Find the hexagon cube coordinates for a given position
// The following is a simplified version of this:
// Hexagon cube coordinates to hexagon position
// The following is a simplified version of this:
// const positionX = Math.sqrt(3) * roundX  + Math.sqrt(3)/2 * roundZ;

parameters.description: Objects to snap to the virtual grid
parameters.name: Object

parameters.description: Width of a cell of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.name: CellWidth

parameters.description: Height of a cell of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.longDescription: The actual row height will be 3/4 of this.
parameters.name: CellHeight

parameters.description: Offset on the X axis of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.name: OffsetX

parameters.description: Offset on the Y axis of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.longDescription: Odd rows are shifted from half a cell, use a "CellHeight * 3/4" offset to make it the other way.
parameters.name: OffsetY

eventsFunctions.description: Snap object to a virtual flat topped hexagonal grid (this is not the grid used in the editor).
eventsFunctions.fullName: Snap objects to a virtual flat topped hexagonal grid
eventsFunctions.name: SnapObjectToFlatToppedHexagonalGrid
eventsFunctions.sentence: Snap _PARAM1_ to a virtual flat topped hexagonal grid using cells with width: _PARAM2_px, height _PARAM3_px and an offset position (_PARAM4_; _PARAM5_)

events.comment: Note: this is the exact same code as for pointy topped hexagonal grid with x and y swapped.

inlineCode: // Find the hexagon cube coordinates for a given position
// The following is a simplified version of this:
// Hexagon cube coordinates to hexagon position
// The following is a simplified version of this:
// const positionX = Math.sqrt(3) * roundX  + Math.sqrt(3)/2 * roundZ;

parameters.description: Objects to snap to the virtual grid
parameters.name: Object

parameters.description: Width of a cell of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.longDescription: The actual column width will be 3/4 of this.
parameters.name: CellWidth

parameters.description: Height of a cell of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.name: CellHeight

parameters.description: Offset on the X axis of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.longDescription: Odd columns are shifted from half a cell, use a "CellHeight * 3/4" offset to make it the other way.
parameters.name: OffsetX

parameters.description: Offset on the Y axis of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.name: OffsetY

eventsFunctions.description: Snap object to a virtual bubble grid (this is not the grid used in the editor).
eventsFunctions.fullName: Snap objects to a virtual bubble grid
eventsFunctions.name: SnapObjectToBubbleGrid
eventsFunctions.sentence: Snap _PARAM1_ to a virtual bubble grid using cells with width: _PARAM2_px, height _PARAM3_px and an offset position (_PARAM4_; _PARAM5_)

events.comment:
This grid is like bottles stacking, odd lines are shifted from half a cell. 

On an hexagonal grid a line height is 3/4 of sprite height but with bubbles it is sin(60) that is around 0.866 which is near 7/8 = 0.875
(7/6)/(3/4) = 7/6
Using this ratio, the cellHeigt gives the 7/8 line height and this allows integer position as assets are often a multiple of 8.

parameters.description: Objects to snap to the virtual grid
parameters.name: Object

parameters.description: Width of a cell of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.name: CellWidth

parameters.description: Height of a cell of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.longDescription: The actual row height will be 7/8 of this.
parameters.name: CellHeight

parameters.description: Offset on the X axis of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.name: OffsetX

parameters.description: Offset on the Y axis of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.longDescription: Odd rows are shifted from half a cell, use a "CellHeight * 7/8" offset to make it the other way
parameters.name: OffsetY

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: FireBullet
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Fire bullets, manage ammo, reloading and overheating.
description: This extension allows objects to fire bullets. To use it, add the behavior to the object that will shoot, then use the provided action to launch another object as the bullet.
The properties of the behavior can be used to customize:
- Cooldown between shots
- Firing multiple bullets at a time ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://fire-bullet))
- Ammo management
- Overheat
The speed can be specified when using the actions to fire the bullets.
The bullets are automatically given a permanent force to make them move in the 2D plane (no need to use a linear movement or move them with another behavior).
It can be used for:
- Twin-stick shooters ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://conviction-of-gun-dude-desktop))
- Shoot'em up ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://space-shooter))
A simple example shows how to make firing patterns ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://firing-patterns)).

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Fire bullets with built-in cooldown, ammo, reloading, and overheating. Once added to your object that must shoot, use the behavior actions to fire another object as a bullet. These actions check all constraints internally (can be called without conditions, they will only fire when ready) and will make the bullet move (using a permanent force).
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: FireBullet

events.comment: Creators can use the "FireBullet" action multiple times in a frame and it will be counted as a single "shot".
Detect when reload is completed
Only reload the amount of ammo available

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Bounce
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Bounce the object off another object it just touched.
description: Provides an action to make the object bounce from another object it just touched.
>  This *won't work* with Physics engine or Platformer characters. This is working with objects that are moved using actions or behaviors using **the forces**.
The Breakout-like example uses this extension to make balls bounce ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://breakout)).

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Provides an action to make the object bounce from another object it just touched. Add a permanent force to the object and, when in collision with another one, use the action to make it bounce realistically.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: Bounce

eventsFunctions.description:
Bounce the object off another object it is currently colliding with, according to the angle and the speed of forces applied on the object.
Make sure to test for a collision between the two objects before launching this action. All the forces will be removed from the object, and a new permanent force will be added to make the object bounce.
eventsFunctions.name: BounceOff

events.comment:
To bounce the object realistically, we first separate it from the obstacle. The collision engine will do it by moving the object through the shortest "normal vector" of the edge that was collided.
We store the position of the object before being moved so that we know the angle of this "normal vector". Once we know it, we add a force in the direction of the normal vector, and we add the difference between the normal vector and the previous angle of movement.

eventsFunctions.description:
Bounce the object off another object it is currently colliding with, according to the angle and the speed of forces applied on the object.
The bounce will always be calculated *to go toward the specified angle (the "normal angle")*. For example, if the object is arriving at this exact angle, it will bounce in the opposite direction.

Make sure to test for a collision between the two objects before launching this action. All the forces will be removed from the object, and a new permanent force will be added to make the object bounce.
eventsFunctions.fullName: Bounce off another object toward a specified angle
eventsFunctions.name: BounceOffSpecificAngle
eventsFunctions.sentence: Bounce _PARAM0_ off _PARAM2_ assuming a normal angle of _PARAM3_

events.comment:
Check if there is a collision between the object and an obstacle and if so, do the bounce by stopping the object and adding a force so that it goes in the "reflected" direction, using the "normal" angle provided. 
This provides a realistic bounce.

parameters.description: The "normal" angle, in degrees, to bounce against
parameters.longDescription: This can be understood at the direction that the bounce must go toward.
parameters.name: NormalAngle

eventsFunctions.description:
Bounce the object off another object it is currently colliding with, according to the angle and the speed of forces applied on the object.
The bounce will always be vertical, like if the object is *colliding a perfectly horizontal obstacle* (like the top/bottom of the screen in a pong game). For example, if the object is arriving with an angle of exactly 90 degrees, it will bounce in the opposite direction: -90 degrees.

Make sure to test for a collision between the two objects before launching this action. All the forces will be removed from the object, and a new permanent force will be added to make the object bounce.
eventsFunctions.name: BounceOffVertically

eventsFunctions.description:
Bounce the object off another object it is currently colliding with, according to the angle and the speed of forces applied on the object.
The bounce will always be horizontal, like if the object is *colliding a perfectly vertical obstacle* (like paddles in a pong game). For example, if the object is arriving with an angle of exactly 0 degrees, it will bounce in the opposite direction: 180 degrees.

Make sure to test for a collision between the two objects before launching this action. All the forces will be removed from the object, and a new permanent force will be added to make the object bounce.
eventsFunctions.name: BounceOffHorizontally

eventsFunctions.description: the number of times this object has bounced off another object.
eventsFunctions.name: BounceCount

propertyDescriptors.label: Bounce count
propertyDescriptors.description: Number of times this object has bounced off another object
propertyDescriptors.name: BounceCount

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: D8H
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: LinkTools
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Conditions to use Linked Objects as a graph and a path finding movement behavior.
description: This provides:
* "Can reach through links" conditions, useful to check if an object is linked to another through one or more other linked objects.
* a path finding movement behavior that uses objects links (instead of obstacles for the other behavior)
For instance, it can be helpful for grid-based games like:
* Match-3 ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://bim-bam))
* Tactical ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://tactical-game-grid-movement))
* City builders ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://city-builder))
* Point and click (bypass obstacles with a predetermined polygonal chain)

eventsFunctions.description: Link to neighbors on a rectangular grid.
eventsFunctions.fullName: Link to neighbors on a rectangular grid
eventsFunctions.name: LinkRectangularNeighbors
eventsFunctions.sentence: Link _PARAM1_ and its neighbors _PARAM2_  on a rectangular grid with cell dimensions: _PARAM3_; _PARAM4_

parameters.longDescription: The 2 objects can't be the same.
parameters.name: Neighbor

eventsFunctions.description: Link to neighbors on a hexagonal grid.
eventsFunctions.fullName: Link to neighbors on a hexagonal grid
eventsFunctions.name: LinkHexagonalNeighbors
eventsFunctions.sentence: Link _PARAM1_ and its neighbors _PARAM2_  on a hexagonal grid with cell dimensions: _PARAM3_; _PARAM4_

parameters.longDescription: The 2 objects can't be the same.
parameters.name: Neighbor

eventsFunctions.name: LinkIsometricRectangularNeighbors
eventsFunctions.sentence: Link _PARAM1_ and its neighbors _PARAM2_  on an isometric grid with cell dimensions: _PARAM3_; _PARAM4_

parameters.longDescription: The 2 objects can't be the same.
parameters.name: Neighbor

eventsFunctions.sentence: Take into account all "_PARAM1_" that can reach _PARAM2_ with initial value from the variable _PARAM3_ through at most a cost of: _PARAM4_ according to cost class: _PARAM5_ and at most _PARAM6_ links depth

inlineCode: * Insert a node in an array sorted by farest 1st
// mark every instance that can be reached through links
// openObjects is the new discovered instances where links must be checked
// nearest last because pop is o(1)
// and it must be in the set given by the caller
// filter the instances to only keep the one marked with the pick attribute

parameters.description: if they can reach this object
parameters.name: TargetObject

parameters.longDescription: Leave empty to make everything crossable with cost = 1. It looks in the variable children of linktools_Cost. No child means not crossable, the cost must be positive.
parameters.name: CostClass

eventsFunctions.name: CanReachWithMaxLength
eventsFunctions.sentence: Take into account all "_PARAM1_" that can reach _PARAM2_ through at most _PARAM3_ links according to cost class: _PARAM4_

inlineCode: // mark every instance that can be reached through links
// openObjects is the new discovered instances where links must be checked
// and it must be in the set given by the caller
// filter the instances to only keep the one marked with the pick attribute

parameters.description: if they can reach this object
parameters.name: TargetObject

parameters.longDescription: Leave empty to make everything crossable with cost = 1. It looks in the variable children of linktools_Cost. No child means not crossable, the cost can be 0 or 1.
parameters.name: CostClass

eventsFunctions.description: Can reach through links.
eventsFunctions.name: CanReach
eventsFunctions.sentence: Take into account all "_PARAM1_" that can reach _PARAM2_ through links

inlineCode: // mark every instance that can be reached through links
// openObjects is the new discovered instances where links must be checked
// and it must be in the set given by the caller
// filter the instances to only keep the one marked with the pick attribute

parameters.description: if they can reach this object
parameters.name: TargetObject

eventsFunctions.description: Cost sum.
eventsFunctions.name: CostSum

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: The object will move from one object instance to another according to how they are linked to one another to reach a targeted object.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: LinkPathFinding

events.comment: Move the object along the path

eventsFunctions.description: Move the object to a position.
eventsFunctions.name: MoveTo
eventsFunctions.sentence: Move _PARAM0_ to _PARAM3_ passing by _PARAM2_ using cost class _PARAM4_

events.comment:
Search the path and set the result in the path variable.
This variable is use by doStepPreEvent to move the object along the path.

inlineCode: * Insert a node in an array sorted by farest 1st
// mark every instance that can be reached through links
// openObjects is the new discovered instances where links must be checked
// and it must be in the set given by the caller
// build the path in the path variable

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the object position is the on a path node.
eventsFunctions.name: HasReachedNode

eventsFunctions.description: Forget the path.
eventsFunctions.name: ForgetPath

eventsFunctions.description: Set next node index
eventsFunctions.name: SetNextNode
eventsFunctions.sentence: Set next node index of _PARAM0_ to _PARAM2_

events.comment: No more nodes
Update the next target

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the object is moving.

eventsFunctions.sentence: A path has been found for _PARAM0_

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the destination was reached.
eventsFunctions.name: HasReachedDestination

eventsFunctions.name: Speed

eventsFunctions.description: Get the number of waypoints on the path.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: D8H
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Turret
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: A turret movement with customizable speed, acceleration and stop angles.
description: With this behavior, you can make an object rotate like a turret toward a position.
It may be used with the **Bullet** extension to fire objects.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: A turret movement with customizable speed, acceleration and stop angles.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: Turret

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the turret is moving.
eventsFunctions.name: IsMoving

eventsFunctions.description: Move clockwise.
eventsFunctions.name: MoveClockwise

eventsFunctions.description: Move counter-clockwise.
eventsFunctions.name: MoveCounterClockwise

events.comment: Origin angle is the farest angle from AngleMin and AngleMax, it's used by MoveToward

eventsFunctions.description: Set angle toward a position.
eventsFunctions.fullName: Set aiming angle toward a position
eventsFunctions.name: SetAimingAngleToward
eventsFunctions.sentence: Set the aiming angle of _PARAM0_ toward _PARAM2_;_PARAM3_

events.comment: Use OriginAngle to obtain an angle that is the nearest from AngleMin and AngleMax

parameters: mod(ToDeg(atan2(TargetY - Object.Y(), TargetX - Object.X())) - OriginAngle, 360) + OriginAngle

eventsFunctions.description: Move toward a position.
eventsFunctions.name: MoveToward

events.comment: Use OriginAngle to obtain an angle that is the nearest from AngleMin and AngleMax

parameters: mod(ToDeg(atan2(TargetY - Object.Y(), TargetX - Object.X())) - OriginAngle, 360) + OriginAngle

events.comment: There is stop angles
No stop angle, the direction is chosen according to the shortest path (never more that 180)

eventsFunctions.description: Change the aiming angle.
eventsFunctions.name: SetAimingAngle
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the aiming angle of _PARAM0_ to _PARAM2_

events.comment: Use mod to avoid the angle value to be too large.
There are stop angles, the angle is bounded by these.

eventsFunctions.description: Aiming angle (between 0 and 360 if no stop angle are set).
eventsFunctions.name: AimingAngle

propertyDescriptors.label: Maximum rotation speed (in degrees per second)
propertyDescriptors.name: SpeedMax

propertyDescriptors.label: Maximum angle (use the same value for min and max to set no constraint)
propertyDescriptors.name: AngleMax

propertyDescriptors.label: Minimum angle (use the same value for min and max to set no constraint)
propertyDescriptors.name: AngleMin

propertyDescriptors.label: Origin angle: the farest angle from AngleMin and AngleMax
propertyDescriptors.name: OriginAngle
